person_556.name: JohnProby
person_556.description: Whig politician and MP. From 1789 first Earl of Carysfort (in the Irish Peeage). Life Subscriber to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_558.name: GraceDavy
person_558.description: Davy's mother who spent her entire life in West Cornwall.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_581.name: Henry CharlesEnglefield
person_581.description: Seventh baronet from 1780 and a prominent Roman Catholic antiquarian and geologist. FRSL.

person_410.name: JamesMacDonnell
person_410.description: Belfast physician who met Davy in 1806, 1811 and 1826.

person_612.name: JamesMcDonnell
person_612.description: Radical Irish physician and supporter of literature who founded the Belfast Literary Society in 1801. Davy met him on one of his visits to Ireland.

person_1078.name: JohnSeymour
person_1078.description: an English aristocrat and amateur geologist. FRS.

place_460.name: Montgomeryshire
place_460.description: Montgomeryshire is a historic county that now forms the northern part of Powys, Wales.

place_659.name: Shropshire
place_659.description: A county in the West Midlands of England.

place_113.name: Severn Estuary
place_113.description: The Severn Estuary is the estuary of the River Severn, flowing into the Bristol Channel between south-west England and south Wales.

place_664.name: Llanychan
place_664.description: Llanychan is a parish near Llandyrnog, Denbighshire, Wales. It is the smallest parish in the diocese of St Asaph.

place_663.name: Llangollen
place_663.description: Llangollen is a town and community, situated on the River Dee, in Denbighshire, Wales.

place_665.name: Berwyn Hills
place_665.description: The Berwyn Range is an isolated and sparsely populated area of moorland in the north-east of Wales, roughly bounded by Llangollen in the north-east, Corwen in the north-west, Bala in the south-west, and Oswestry in the south-east.

place_458.name: Caernarfonshire
place_458.description: Caernarfonshire is a county in the north west of Wales.

place_453.name: Capel Curig
place_453.description: Capel Curig is a village in Caernarfonshire, in the heart of Snowdonia.

place_668.name: Nant Ffrancon
place_668.description: A steep-sided glacial valley dropping to Bethesda between the Glyderau and the Carneddau, Wales.

place_669.name: Ogwen Quarry
place_669.description: Probably Penrhyn Quarry, which produced Ogwen slate in the Ogwen Valley in Wales.

place_454.name: Corwen
place_454.description: Corwen is a town in Denbighshire, Wales.

place_1354.name: Bettws, Bridgend
place_1354.description: a small ex-mining and farming village in the South Wales Valleys in the county borough of Bridgend, Wales.

place_456.name: Cader Idris
place_456.description: Cader Idris is a mountain in Merionnydd, near Dolgellau, Wales.

place_457.name: Llyn Ogwen
place_457.description: Llyn Ogwen is a ribbon lake in Snowdonia, lying between the mountains of the Carneddau and Glyderau.

place_447.name: Dolgellau
place_447.description: Dolgellau is a town in the county of Gwynedd, north Wales.

place_448.name: Beddgelert
place_448.description: Beddgelert is a village in the Snowdonia area of the county of Gwynedd, Wales.

place_449.name: Penmorfa
place_449.description: Penmorfa is a village close to Porthmadog in Gwynedd, Wales.

place_450.name: Caernarfon
place_450.description: Caernarfon is a town and port in Caernarfonshire, Wales.

place_459.name: Denbighshire
place_459.description: Denbighshire is a county in mid-north Wales.

place_1355.name: Bangor, Wales
place_1355.description: Bangor is a cathedral city and community in Gwynedd, North Wales. It is the oldest city in Wales.

place_495.name: Bangor, County Down
place_495.description: Bangor is a coastal town in County Down, Northern Ireland. It lies on the southern shore of Belfast Lough.

place_483.name: Tal-y-llyn, Gwynedd
place_483.description: Tal-y-llyn, or Talyllyn, is a small hamlet and former parish in the community of Llanfihangel-y-Pennant in Gwynedd, Wales, situated at the end of Tal-y-llyn Lake close to the village of Abergynolwyn. For much of the 19th century, and the first half of the 20th century, the predominant industry in the area was slate mining, in the quarries at Bryn Eglwys and Corris.

place_646.name: County Kilkenny
place_646.description: A county in south-eastern Ireland. Historically, places such as Castlecomer had lots of coal mines, with sixteen pits there in 1802.

place_470.name: Killiney
place_470.description: Killiney is a coastal area of County Dublin, Ireland. In the 19th Century it was a popular seaside resort and many of the pebbles and rocks along Killiney Beach are examples of carboniferous limestone, some of which contain fossils of corals, sea shells and other sea life that existed millions of years ago.

place_790.name: Yr Wyddfa
place_790.description: Also known as Snowdon. The highest mountain peak in Wales.

place_791.name: Aran Fawddwy
place_791.description: A mountain in southern Snowdonia or Eryri, Wales.

place_792.name: Caernarfon
place_792.description: A Welsh town that has views of Snowdonia.

place_461.name: Anglesey
place_461.description: Anglesey is an island, and county, on the north-west coast of Wales.

place_462.name: Beaumaris
place_462.description: Beaumaris is a town on the Isle of Anglesey in North Wales, well known for its 13th-century castle.

place_765.name: Cemlyn
place_765.description: On the north coast ofÂ Anglesey, Wales.

place_655.name: Parys Mine
place_655.description: A mountain in Northern Wales known for copper-mining.

place_044.name: Wicklow
place_044.description: County Wicklow is a county in Ireland on the east coast, south of Dublin.

place_481.name: Wicklow Bay
place_481.description: Wicklow Bay is on the east coast of Ireland, south of Dublin. Wicklow town is the harbour in the bay.

place_045.name: Wicklow Mountains
place_045.description: The Wicklow Mountains are the largest upland area in the Republic of Ireland, located on the east coast. They are formed largely of granite.

place_122.name: Wales
place_122.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

place_469.name: County Dublin
place_469.description: County Dublin is located on the eastern coast of Ireland.

place_036.name: Kildare
place_036.description: Kildare is a town in County Kildare, Ireland.

place_477.name: River Slaney
place_477.description: The River Slaney is a river in south-east Ireland, in part flowing through County Wicklow.

place_478.name: Grangecon
place_478.description: Grangecon is a village in County Wicklow, Ireland.

place_682.name: Glenmalure
place_682.description: A glacial valley in the Wicklow Mountains in Ireland.

place_683.name: Cronebane
place_683.description: A townland in County Wicklow, Ireland.

place_684.name: Croghan Mountain
place_684.description: In Wicklow, Ireland, a location of a late eighteenth-century gold rush.

place_679.name: The Devils Glen
place_679.description: A forested area in County Wicklow, Ireland.

place_681.name: Glen of the Downs
place_681.description: The Glen of the Downs is a 2 km long wooded glacial valley with steep sides rising to almost 250m on the east coast of Ireland.

place_486.name: Powerscourt
place_486.description: Powerscourt Estate, Enniskerry, County Wicklow, Ireland.

place_810.name: River Dargle
place_810.description: A river that flows from the Wicklow Mountains to the Irish Sea. It forms a waterfull at the Powerscourt Estate.

place_1356.name: An Scailp
place_1356.description: An Scailp on the border of counties Wicklow & Dublin means '(the) rocky chasm', a name which accurately describes that valley.

place_399.name: Dublin
place_399.description: The capital city of the Republic of Ireland.

place_471.name: Dundalk
place_471.description: Dundalk is the county town of County Louth in Ireland.

place_472.name: Newry
place_472.description: Newry is a city in the counties of Armagh and Down in southern Northern Ireland.

place_473.name: Lough Neagh
place_473.description: Lough Neagh is a freshwater lake in Northern Ireland, and the largest lake in Ireland.

place_474.name: Coalisland
place_474.description: Coalisland is a town in County Tyrone in Northern Ireland.

place_480.name: Coleraine
place_480.description: Coleraine is a town in County Derry, Northern Ireland.

place_146.name: Portrush
place_146.description: A small seaside town on north coast of County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_479.name: Pleaskin Cliff
place_479.description: Pleaskin Head is a cliff that is part of the Giant's Causeway coastline, Northern Ireland.

place_126.name: Giant's Causeway
place_126.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

place_076.name: Magilligan
place_076.description: A peninsula in north-west County Londonderry in Northern Ireland.

place_127.name: Dunluce
place_127.description: Dunluce is the site of a ruined castle on the Antrim coastline, Northern Ireland.

place_498.name: Craigahulliar Quarry
place_498.description: Craigahulliar Quarry is 2km to the east of Portrush, Northern Ireland. It is cut into basaltic lava flows with characteristic columnar jointing.

place_128.name: Ballintoy
place_128.description: Ballintoy is a village on County Antrim's Giant's Causeway Coast, Northern Ireland.

place_134.name: Rathlin Island
place_134.description: An island off the coast of County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_130.name: Carrick-a-rede
place_130.description: Davy's reference may apply to the rope bridge connecting the mainland near Ballintoy with the small island of Carrickarede. It was built 250 years ago.

place_132.name: Fairhead
place_132.description: Fairhead is a spectacular 5km long, 82m high cliff above the sea at Ballycastle, County Antrim, Northern Ireland. It is a dolerite sill.

place_135.name: Ballycastle, County Antrim
place_135.description: A small town in County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_482.name: Doagh
place_482.description: Doagh is a village in County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_763.name: Sandy Braes
place_763.description: Perhaps part of the Tardree Mountain complex, County Antrim, Northern Ireland, a volcanic vent complex with very rare rocks, which belong to the Tardree Rhyolite Complex, or Sallagh Braes, a mountain in County Antrim.

place_077.name: Belfast
place_077.description: Belfast is the capital city of Northern Ireland.

place_301.name: County Antrim
place_301.description: A county in north-eastern Northern Ireland.

place_487.name: County Down
place_487.description: County Down is a county in the south-east of Northern Ireland.

place_494.name: Mourne Mountains
place_494.description: Slieve Donard is located in the Mourne Mountains of County Down, Northern Ireland. It is Northern Ireland's highest mountain at 850m.

place_047.name: Donegal
place_047.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

place_496.name: Mull of Galloway
place_496.description: The Mull of Galloway is the headland of a peninsula in south-west Scotland, across the Irish Sea from County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_488.name: Whitehaven
place_488.description: Whitehaven is a town on the west coast of the Lake District county of Cumbria. Historically it was in Cumberland.

place_079.name: Cumberland
place_079.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

place_078.name: Westmorland
place_078.description: Westmoreland is a historic county in north-west England spanning the southern Lake District and northern Dales.

place_489.name: Kendal
place_489.description: Kendal is a market town in the Lake District County of Cumbria.

place_670.name: Helvellyn
place_670.description: A mountain in the English Lake District. Davy climbed this on 14 August 1805 with William Wordsworth and Walter Scott.

place_755.name: Skiddaw
place_755.description: A mountain in the Lake District, near Keswick.

place_754.name: Maryport
place_754.description: A town in Cumbria, near the Lake District.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_490.name: Buxton
place_490.description: Buxton is a spa town in Derbyshire, England.

place_491.name: Ashbourne, Derbyshire
place_491.description: Ashbourne is a town in Derbyshire, England, close to the entrance of Dovedale.

place_492.name: Derby
place_492.description: Derby is an English city on the banks of the River Derwent in Derbyshire.

place_493.name: Coleorton
place_493.description: Coleorton is a village in Leicestershire and the location of Coleorton Hall, the home of George Beaumont, friend of William Wordsworth, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, and Davy.

place_082.name: Breedon on the Hill
place_082.description: Breedon-on-the-Hill is a village on the Derbyshire-Leicestershire border. It is next to a limestone quarry.

place_507.name: Charnwood Forest
place_507.description: The Charnwood Forest is a upland area in Leicestershire, the highest point being 278m. The geology is remarkable as Precambrian igneous rocks, some of the oldest rocks on earth, are seen as isolated outcrops, as in Davy's sketch.

place_485.name: Mountsorrel
place_485.description: Mountsorrel is a village in Leicestershire bordering the Charnwood Forest, an upland area with isolated outcrops of ancient Precambrian igneous rocks.

place_777.name: Ogwen Valley
place_777.description: A valley mostly located in the Welsh county of Gwynedd.

place_497.name: Loch Lomond
place_497.description: Loch Lomond is a Scottish fresh water loch which crosses the Highland Boundary Fault.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.
